slides.title: Introduction to Maternal Health
slides.content:
**Why Maternal Health Matters**

Healthy mother = Healthy baby!

**Your Role with Pregnant Women:**
- Identify pregnant women in community
- Encourage antenatal checkups
- Provide supplementary nutrition
- Health education
- Link with ANM and health services

**Topics Covered:**
- Pregnancy care
- Antenatal checkups
- Nutrition during pregnancy
- Warning signs
- Postnatal care

**Impact:** Proper care prevents maternal and infant mortality.

slides.title: Antenatal Care (ANC)
slides.content:
**Care During Pregnancy**

**Minimum 4 ANC Checkups Required:**

**1st Checkup (within 12 weeks):**
- Registration
- Complete checkup
- Blood tests
- TT injection 1
- IFA tablets start
- Advice on nutrition

**2nd Checkup (14-26 weeks):**
- Weight and BP check
- Abdominal examination
- TT injection 2
- Continue IFA tablets

**3rd Checkup (28-34 weeks):**
- Weight and BP
- Baby's position check
- Blood tests

**4th Checkup (36-40 weeks):**
- Delivery preparation
- Danger signs education
- Birth plan discussion

**Every Visit:** Check weight, BP, urine test, baby's heartbeat

slides.title: Nutrition During Pregnancy
slides.content:
**Eating for Two? - Quality Matters!**

**Increased Nutritional Needs:**

**Energy:**
- Extra 350 kcal/day (2nd & 3rd trimester)
- Eat one extra meal

**Protein:**
- Extra 23 grams/day
- Sources: Dal, milk, eggs, meat

**Iron:**
- Very important!
- Prevents anemia
- IFA tablets daily (100 mg iron + 0.5 mg folic acid)
- Take with vitamin C (lemon water)
- Don't take with tea/milk

**Calcium:**
- For baby's bones
- Sources: Milk, yogurt, ragi, green leafy vegetables
- 1000 mg/day needed

**Folic Acid:**
- Prevents birth defects
- Start before pregnancy if possible
- Green leafy vegetables

**What to Eat:**
- Balanced diet daily
- Extra milk, dal, vegetables
- Fruits (especially seasonal)
- Plenty of water (8-10 glasses)

**Avoid:** Junk food, alcohol, tobacco, raw meat

slides.title: Danger Signs in Pregnancy
slides.content:
**Emergency Warning Signs - Refer IMMEDIATELY!**

**Any of these signs needs urgent medical attention:**

**Bleeding:**
- Vaginal bleeding (any amount)
- During any stage of pregnancy

**Severe Headache:**
- With blurred vision
- Could be preeclampsia

**Swelling:**
- Sudden swelling of face, hands, feet
- Especially with high BP

**Severe Abdominal Pain:**
- Persistent pain
- With or without bleeding

**High Fever:**
- Temperature >100°F
- With chills

**Reduced Fetal Movements:**
- Baby not moving as usual
- No movements for several hours

**Leaking Water:**
- Water bag broken
- Wetness from vagina

**Convulsions/Fits:**
- Eclampsia - life threatening!

**Action:** Don't wait - refer to hospital immediately!

slides.title: Immunization During Pregnancy
slides.content:
**Tetanus Toxoid (TT) Vaccination**

**Why TT Vaccine?**
- Prevents tetanus in mother and newborn
- Neonatal tetanus is fatal
- Must be given to all pregnant women

**Schedule:**

**If Never Vaccinated:**
- TT1: As early as possible in pregnancy
- TT2: 4 weeks after TT1

**If Vaccinated as Child:**
- TT Booster: One dose during pregnancy

**Full Protection Needs 5 Doses:**
- TT1 (first contact)
- TT2 (4 weeks later)
- TT3 (6 months later or next pregnancy)
- TT4 (1 year later or next pregnancy)
- TT5 (1 year later or next pregnancy)
- Protection lasts lifelong after 5 doses

**Your Role:**
- Track vaccination status
- Mobilize for TT camps
- Ensure every pregnant woman gets TT
- Maintain records

slides.title: Common Pregnancy Discomforts
slides.content:
**Normal Problems and Solutions**

**Morning Sickness (Nausea/Vomiting):**
- Common in first 3 months
- Eat small, frequent meals
- Avoid spicy, oily food
- Dry crackers before getting up
- If severe (can't keep anything down): Refer

**Constipation:**
- Eat fibrous foods (vegetables, fruits)
- Drink plenty of water
- Exercise/walk
- Iron tablets can worsen it

**Backache:**
- Good posture
- Avoid heavy lifting
- Gentle exercises

**Leg Cramps:**
- Stretch legs
- Massage
- Adequate calcium

**Heartburn:**
- Small, frequent meals
- Avoid lying down immediately after eating
- Avoid spicy food

**Swelling of Feet:**
- Rest with feet elevated
- If sudden/severe with headache: Danger sign! Refer

**Advice:** These are normal but if severe, consult doctor.

slides.title: Birth Preparedness
slides.content:
**Planning for Safe Delivery**

**Every pregnant woman should have a Birth Plan:**

**Where to Deliver?**
- Institutional delivery recommended
- Government hospital/PHC free
- Skilled birth attendant essential

**Who Will Accompany?**
- Husband/family member
- Arrange transport in advance

**Emergency Fund:**
- Save money for emergency
- Know about government schemes (Janani Suraksha Yojana)

**Things to Keep Ready (by 8 months):**
- Clean clothes for mother and baby
- Sanitary pads
- Towels
- Baby clothes and nappies
- Important documents (ANC card, Aadhaar)

**Know the Facility:**
- Where is nearest health facility?
- How to reach (transport)?
- Phone number of ANM/doctor

**Your Role:**
- Discuss birth plan during home visits
- Encourage institutional delivery
- Link with JSY scheme

slides.title: Postnatal Care - Mother
slides.content:
**Care After Delivery (0-6 weeks)**

**Immediate Care (First 24 hours):**
- Check for bleeding
- Initiate breastfeeding within 1 hour
- Keep mother warm
- Monitor BP

**First Week:**
- Rest as much as possible
- Nutritious food
- Plenty of fluids (for milk production)
- Personal hygiene
- Check for danger signs

**Nutrition Postpartum:**
- Continue IFA tablets for 6 months
- Extra meal per day
- Plenty of fluids
- Balanced diet

**Danger Signs After Delivery - Refer if:**
- Heavy bleeding (soaking >2 pads/hour)
- Foul-smelling discharge
- High fever
- Severe abdominal pain
- Swollen, painful breast (mastitis)
- Severe headache with vision problems
- Sadness/depression (postpartum depression)

**Family Planning Counseling:**
- Discuss spacing methods
- Lactational amenorrhea (not reliable)
- Modern methods available

slides.title: Government Schemes for Mothers
slides.content:
**Support for Pregnant and Lactating Women**

**Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY):**
- Cash benefit of ₹5,000
- For first living child
- 3 installments:
  - ₹1,000 on early registration
  - ₹2,000 after 6 months pregnancy with one ANC
  - ₹2,000 after delivery and BCG vaccination

**Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY):**
- Cash incentive for institutional delivery
- Amount varies by state (₹600-1,400)
- For BPL families

**Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK):**
- Free delivery in government hospitals
- Free medicines and investigations
- Free diet during stay
- Free transport (to and from hospital)

**Supplementary Nutrition (SNP):**
- Through Anganwadi
- Take-home ration
- 600 kcal + 18-20 g protein/day

**Your Role:**
- Inform eligible women
- Help with documentation
- Ensure benefits reach them

question.questionText: How many minimum antenatal checkups (ANC) are recommended during pregnancy?
question.explanation: Minimum 4 antenatal checkups (ANC) are recommended during pregnancy: 1st within 12 weeks, 2nd at 14-26 weeks, 3rd at 28-34 weeks, and 4th at 36-40 weeks. More checkups may be needed if there are complications.
